org.ambraproject.rhino.util.response

Class Transceiver

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.ambraproject.rhino.util.response.Transceiver
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    EntityCollectionTransceiver, EntityTransceiver

    public abstract class Transceiver
extends Object
    This class encapsulates data returned from the service layer and presents it to the controller layer.

    This class bridges a gap between the two layers and fills a different role for each. To the service layer, this class is an interface that defines callbacks (the protected abstract methods) for such operations as retrieving an object from persistence or looking up a last-modified timestamp (and maybe more in the future). To the controller layer, this class is a utility that (using the respond(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest, javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse, com.google.gson.Gson) method) parses a RESTful request and formats the response. The service layer should never need to see types like HttpServletRequest and HttpServletResponse, and the controller layer should never need to see the actual data entities being served.

    The class name uses the metaphor of a "transceiver" because of this dual role: in the service layer, it receives data from persistence; in the controller layer, it transmits responses to the client.

    Generally, one instance of this class is constructed (in the service layer) per service call. For example, there is a call to read an article's metadata, so the service constructs a Transceiver object that reads the metadata for that particular article. Typically this would be done by passing the relevant identifier to the subclass's constructor or, more often, referring to it closure-style from inside an anonymous subclass.

    • Method Detail

      • getData

        protected abstract Object getData()
                           throws IOException
        Get an object representing the data that is being requested from the service. It will be serialized to JSON to form the response.
        Returns:
        the object
        Throws:
        IOException

      • getLastModifiedDate

        protected abstract Calendar getLastModifiedDate()
                                         throws IOException
        Return the last-modified date for this object's data. May return null for volatile data that always may be assumed to have been modified since it was last accessed, or if looking up the last-modified date is unsupported.
        Returns:
        the date
        Throws:
        IOException

      • copyToCalendar

        protected static Calendar copyToCalendar(Date date)
        Copy a Date object to a Calendar object.
        Parameters:
        date - the Date object
        Returns:
        an equivalent Calendar object

      • respond

        public final void respond(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest request,
           javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse response,
           com.google.gson.Gson gson)
                   throws IOException
        Respond with data according to a request.

        If the request contains a "Last-Modified" header and the value in question has not been modified since the given date, respond with a 304 ("Not Modified") status code and omit the rest of the response.

        If the request provides a JSONP callback parameter, use it to provide a JSONP response.

        Parameters:
        request - a service request
        response - the object that will receive the response
        gson - an object containing the context's rules for serializing data to responses
        Throws:
        IOException

      • readJson

        public String readJson(com.google.gson.Gson gson)
                throws IOException
        Dump this object's response directly to a string as JSON. For testing only.
        Parameters:
        gson - an object containing the context's rules for serializing data to responses
        Returns:
        the response body as a JSON string
        Throws:
        IOException

      • bufferResponseBody

        protected boolean bufferResponseBody()
        Returns:
        true if responses should be buffered fully to memory before opening a response stream
        See Also:
        serializeSafely(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest, javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse, com.google.gson.Gson, java.lang.Object), serializeDirectly(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest, javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse, com.google.gson.Gson, java.lang.Object)
